Identification of Drug-Target Interactions via Multiple Information Integration Yijie Ding
Identification of Drug-Target Interactions via Multiple Information Integration

biblStruct.note: Received date: 5 June 2017 Revised date: 9 August 2017 Accepted date: 11 August 2017 Preprint submitted to Journal of Information Sciences Templates

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Identifying Drug-Target Interactions (DTIs) is an important process in drug discovery. Traditional experimental methods are expensive and timeconsuming for detecting DTIs. Therefore, computational approaches provide many effective strategies to deal with this issue. In recent years, most of computational methods only use the information of drug-drug similarity or target-target similarity, which cannot perfectly capture all characteristics to identify DTIs. In this paper, we propose a novel computational model of DTIs prediction, based on machine learning methods. To improve the performance of prediction, we further use molecular substructure fingerprints, Multivariate Mutual Information (MMI) of proteins and network topology to represent drugs, targets and relationship between them. Moreover, we employ Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Feature Selection (FS) to construct model for predicting DTIs. Experiments of evaluation show that proposed approach achieves better results than other outstanding methods for feature-based DTIs prediction. The proposed approach achieves AUPRs of 0.899, 0.929, 0.821 and 0.655 on Enzyme, Ion Channel (IC), GPCR and Nuclear Receptor datasets, respectively. Compared with existing best methods, AUPRs are increased by 0.016 on Ion Channel datasets. In addition, our method obtains the second best performance on

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Many biological signaling pathways involve autocrine ligand-receptor interactions, and cells contain lots of highly specific targets. Drugs act on the cell membrane by physical and chemical interactions. The analysis of DTIs is a key role of the drug discovery process, and many researchers spend a lot of 5 attentions in drug development on filtering receptor binding compounds. The computational technique is able to promote ligand research in an innovative drug-design environment.

In drug discovery, researchers require some labels to mark the binding of a drug to its receptor, which costs extra time and high error rate. Furthermore, 10 a quantitative ranking of drug-target interactions can be valuable in the drug discovery. Thus, it is very important to develop an efficient computational approach to detect DTIs. The interaction network is retrieved from the BRENDA [23], KEGG BRITE [16], SuperTarget [15] and DrugBank [17] databases. Most of the computational method is based on diversified information, including chemical 15 structure of drugs, sequence of proteins, network of instances.

In general, these computational methods can be classified as the following: docking simulation methods and machine learning methods. Docking simulation methods detect DTIs through the structural information of targets. But it is more time-consuming, compared with machine learning techniques. Determining 3D 20 structures of target is still quite difficult to obtain. So, lots of methods based on machine learning were developed to predict DTIs. The machine learning has been widely used in bioinformatics, and achieved very good results [28,2,31]. The

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: DTIs prediction can be regarded as a binary classification problem. What's more, machine learning methods can be subdivided into two subtypes: kernel matrices 25 method via similarity measures (i.e., genomic, chemical and pharmacological spaces) and feature vector-based method (DTI pairs are represented as feature vectors).

The main strategy of kernel matrices-based methods is to build kernel matrices through similarity between drugs and similarity between targets. Each DTIs Bayesian Matrix Factorization with Twin Kernels (KBMF2K) by Gönen, M. [12],

Regularized Least Squares model (RLS) by Laarhoven et al. [27], Bipartite Local Model (BLM) by Bleakley et al. [3], Bipartite Local Mode with Neighbor-based 40 Interaction-profile Inferring (BLM-NII) by Mei et al. [19], Laplacian Regularized Least Square based on interaction network (NetLapRLS) by Xia et al. [32],

Weighted Nearest Neighbor with Gaussian Interaction Profile kernels (WNN-GIP) by Laarhoven et al. [26], Collaborative Matrix Factorization (CMF) by Zheng et al. [35] and Neighborhood Regularized Logistic Matrix Factorization (NRLMF) 45 by Liu et al. [18]. NormMulInf is a semi-supervised learning framework, through collaborative filtering theory by Peng et al. [22]. But the defect of the most kernel-based methods is that there are lots of samples to be classified with remarkable computational complexity. In addition, they did not consider the biological information in the protein domain. These methods did not fully 50 describe the protein sequence through some physical and chemical properties of amino acids. These properties can improve part of the prediction accuracy.
To avoid the problem, other machine learning approaches of feature vectorbased method extracted both drug and target features from molecular fingerprint
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: of drug and sequence descriptors of target as well as known drug-target inter-55 actions [7,6,20]. Cao et al. [7,6] properties of protein sequences. In recent years, the similar approaches of sequence descriptors have been widely used to the protein-protein interaction prediction [24,10]. These substructures of drug and amino acid properties are 75 the key to detect DTI pairs. The DTIs are due to some substructures of drug binding with residues of target through the physical and chemical properties.

Therefore, MACCS and MMI can improve the prediction accuracy. From the perspective of polypharmacology, the network feature could be considered as a pharmacology properties [6]. Limits of mainstream works (kernel matrices-based methods) mainly come 95 from the following aspects: (1) they did not consider the amino acid composition of target protein, when the similarity kernel matrix of target was constructed;

(2) the substructures of drug are redundant, and some of substructure are not presence; (3) lots of methods did not utilize the properties of network topology to build model. For above three problems, our approach has handled them by 100 some strategies. One of critical tasks of detecting DTIs by machine learning methods is feature extraction of DTIs. In this study, the protein representation method of mutual information is firstly utilized in the field of DTIs prediction.

In a protein sequence, mutual information of two amino acids describes the mutual dependence between these two amino acids. It deeply reflects amino acid 105 combinations in sequence. In addition, the dimension of original MACCS feature is redundant. Different from previous methods, we employ FS technology to reduce the redundant noise of feature space. The known relationships of DTIs are also extracted to improve prediction performance. The results of experiment confirms that the prediction performance of our model is comparable or even 110 better than state-of-the-art methods.

div.head: Materials and Methods
div.p: In order to detect DTIs by computational approaches, we need to use a suitable way to represent the critical information of DTIs. The interaction between

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T drug and target protein greatly depends on the information not only from the 115 molecular substructure of drug compound but also from target protein sequence.

So, we represent drugs by utilizing their molecular substructure fingerprints and use k-gram representation to calculate MMI from protein sequences. Because the DTIs network profiling is essentially a cross-pharmacology-related profiling, the topology information of total training network could improve the performance 120 of prediction. Here, we use above DTIs information, FS technique and SVM to build prediction model for identifying DTIs.

div.head: Representing Drug with Molecular Substructure Fingerprint
div.p: Here, we utilize molecular substructure fingerprints to describe drug. Molecular substructure fingerprint directly encodes the structure as a binary vector, 125 which can represent the presence or absence of some specific substructures in one drug. Moreover, it does not need 3D structure of the drug molecule. The fingerprint of MACCS has a MDL dictionary. The definition of MACCS fingerprint is available from OpenBabel (http://openbabel.org/). For MACCS fingerprint, chemical information (chem) of the drug is represented as a feature 130 vector f chem-M ACCS , via 166 common substructures. A demo of fingerprint with substructure dictionary is shown in Figure 1.

div.head: Representing Target Protein with Multivariate Mutual Information from
Amino Acid Sequence
div.p: Inspired by previous works [24], we utilize a novel approach to represent 135 critical information of targets. The k is the number of conjoint amino acids, and Shen et al. [24] used the 3-gram feature representation. To obtain the neighboring local information of residues and their proximate amino acids, they developed a conjoint triad method. On the basis of k-gram feature description, we use MMI [9] for fully representing amino acids in sequences. amino acid types could be clustered into seven functional groups [24], which are detailedly shown in Table 1. As a result, all amino acids in sequences can be 145 divided into seven categories as C 0 , C 1 , ..., C 6 .
Table 1: Division of twenty amino acid types, based on dipoles and volumes of side chains.

div.head: No.
div.p: Group Dipole scale Volume scale
div.formula: C 0 A, G, V Dipole < 1.0 Volume< 50 C 1 C 1.0 < Dipole < 2.0 (form disulphide bonds) Volume> 50 C 2 D, E Dipole > 3.0 (opposite orientation) Volume> 50 C 3 F, I, L, P Dipole < 1.0 Volume> 50 C 4 H, N, Q, W 2.0 < dipole < 3.0 Volume> 50 C 5 K, R Dipole> 3.0 Volume> 50 C 6 M, S, T, Y 1.0 < dipole < 2.0 Volume> 50 A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 2.2.

div.head: Calculating Multivariate Mutual Information
div.p: Any 3 continuous amino acids are regarded as an unit. We only think about the basic ingredient of 3-length unit, and not consider about the order of three amino acids. The types of 3-gram is represented as
div.formula: C 0 , C 0 , C 0 , C 0 , C 0 , C 1 , ..., 150 C 6 , C 6 , C 6 . What's more, the 2-gram are C 0 , C 0 , C 0 , C 1 , ..., C 6 , C 6 .
div.p: The numbers of 2-gram and 3-gram are counted by the sliding window, which is shown in Figure 2.
div.formula: C 0 ={A,G,V} C 1 ={C} C 2 ={D,E} C 3 ={F,I,L,P} C 4 ={H,N,Q,W} C 5 ={K,R} C 6 ={M,S,T,Y} G Y AM T E C H W N Y R Transform encode C 0 C 6 C 0 C 6 C 6 C 2 C 1 C 4 C 4 C 4 C 6 C 5

div.head: Original sequence
div.p: Re-encoding sequence In our work, the entropy and mutual information (MI) refer to mutual dependence between two amino acids on sequence. We calculate the 3-tuples MI 155 for 3-gram as:

div.head: The number of occurrences
div.formula: I(a, b, c) = I(a, b) -I(a, b|c)(1)
div.p: where a, b and c are categories of three conjoint amino acids in one unit.
Then, the MI of I(a, b) and conditional MI of I(a, b|c) can be calculate as:
div.formula: I(a, b) = f (a, b)log( f (a, b) f (a)f (b) ) (2a) I(a, b|c) = H(a|c) -H(a|b, c)(2b)
div.p: where f (a, b) is the frequency of a and b arising in 2-gram on one amino acid sequence, and f (a) is the frequency of a arising on one amino acid sequence.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The H(a|c) and H(a|b, c) are calculated as:
div.formula: H(a|c) = -f (a|c)log(f (a|c)) (3a) = - f (a, c) f (c) log( f (a, c) f (c) ) (3b) H(a|b, c) = -f (a|b, c)log(f (a|b, c)) (3c) = - f (a, b, c) f (b, c) log( f (a, b, c) f (b, c) ) (3d)
div.p: where f (a, b, c) denotes the frequency of a, b and c appearing in 3-tuples on one amino acid sequence.
To avoid values of 3-tuples and 2-tuples MI being infinity, we define the 160 frequency as:
where L denotes the length of sequence, n a denotes the occurrence number of category a appearing on this amino acid sequence. f (a, b) and f (a, b, c) are also calculated by the similar method.

div.head: DTIs Network Topology
div.p: The DTI network could be considered as a bipartite graph, which contains edges describing real DTIs. Cao et al. [6] and Xia et al. [32] incorporated the network information to analyze DTIs. DTI network topology can be considered as a features of pharmacology.
We can obtain the interaction information of one drug

div.head: Feature Selection and Support Vector Machine Model Construction
div.p: The feature space of drug-target complex is made up of bio (MMI), chem Then, it will rank the features based on their significances. Finally, we select top-ranked features as the input vector to training the new SVM model.
The architecture of our proposed method is shown in Figure 3.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

We test our method on balanced DTIs datasets described by Cao et al. [6] to evaluate the performance of our model. First, we analyze the performance of features, containing bio-MMI, chem-MACCS and net. The SVM-RFE+CBR [33] technique is also employed in the balanced DTIs datasets. Second, we compare our approach with other outstanding methods containing BLM by Bleakley NetLapRLS by Xia et al. [32], multiple features fusion by Cao et al. [6] on the balanced bechmark datasets [6]. The proposed method achieves the better values of AUCs, which are 0.985, 0.988, 0.952 and 0.945 on four balanced datasets, respectively.

The imbalanced DTIs datasets are also used to evaluate our method. And we compare the proposed method with other methods containing NetLapRLS [32], WNN-GIP [26], BLM-NII [19], KBMF2K [12], CMF [35], NormMulInf [22] and NRLMF [18]. Our method achieves average AUCs of 0.983, 0.991, 0.961 and 0.916 on four imbalanced datasets, respectively.
Park and Marcotte [21] indicated that the flaw of pair-input prediction existed in many previous computational methods. Thus, we test our approach based on Park's evaluation method.
At last, we test the performance of potential DTIs of our method on benchmark. We set the balanced DTIs as training sets.

div.head: Gold Standard Dataset
div.p: A gold standard dataset is used as a benchmark to evaluate our work, which was released by Yamanishi et al. [34]. All drug-target interacting or noninteracting pairs were taken from BRENDA [23], DrugBank [17], SuperTarget [15] and KEGG BRITE [16] databases.

Targets in these databases can be categorized into four species, including enzymes, IC, GPCR and nuclear receptors, as shown in To resolve unbalanced problem of DTIs, some researchers [30,7,6,20] randomly selected negative samples from unknow interacting pairs, in order to make the size of negative samples reaching to the size of positive samples. So,
we evaluate our method on the mentioned dataset, which is collected by Cao et al. [6]. The details of balanced dataset are described in Cao's work [6] .

div.head: Imbalanced Dataset
div.p: The gold standard dataset only has positive samples, so remaining noninteraction drug-target pairs are regarded as negative. As a result, the number 240 of non-interaction pairs (majority class) is much more than that of interaction pairs (minority class), and the ratio is larger than 99 (292554 : 2926) on Enzyme, 28 (41364 : 1476) on Ion channel, 32 (20550 : 635) on GPCR, and 14 (1314 : 90) on Nuclear classes. In addition, we also test the feedforward neural networks on the balanced 290 datasets. Alhamdoosh and Wang [1,29] employed the Random Vector Functional Link (RVFL) networks as base components, and incorporated with the Negative Correlation Learning (NCL) strategy for building neural network ensembles.

div.head: Evaluation Measurements
div.p: Their proposed algorithm was named as fast Decorrelated Neural Network Ensembles (DNNE) [1]. The results are also shown in Table 3. The DNNE is 295 better than SVM (non feature selection) on Enzymes (0.9821 over 0.9815), and Ion Channel (0.9841 over 0.9817), respectively. And the performance of DNNE is close to RF model. The main reason of the result is that the neural network could Feature Mapping (FM) [29] and DNNE is also an ensemble learning approach.
The hidden feature vectors of each base RVFL network in the ensemble model 300 cover different regions in the feature space.

div.head: Selecting Top Rank Features
div.p: Many features are either redundant or irrelevant, and some of them can be removed without incurring much loss of information. The dimension of original bio-MMI feature and chem-MACCS is 119 and 166, respectively. However, not 305 all of drug molecular substructures are present in these drugs of four datasets.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T In the Table 4, we can see that each type of feature can be selected as part of it. The dimension of original chem-MACCS is 166. Some dimensions of the chem-MACCS feature are all 0 value. And, we remove the these dimensions of the Among them, the network features occupy more than one-third. What's more, the bio-MMI and chem-MACCS features are also essential. On Enzyme and GPCR, the percentages of selected bio-MMI feature are 84.9% (101/119) 340 and 73.1% (87/119), respectively. On the GPCR, the percentage of selected chem-MACCS feature is 80.0% (120/150). However, more features are also removed by SVM-RFE+CBR. On the Nuclear Receptor, 78.9% ((119-25)/119) of bio-MMI feature and 93.5% ((139-9)/139) of chem-MACCS feature are removed, respectively. 345

div.head: Comparing with Existing Approaches
div.p: We compare our model with other existing predictors throught five-fold cross validation on balanced dataset for four species, as showed in Table 5. These methods include BGL[34], BLM [3], NetLapRLS [32], RLS [27], Bigram-PSSM [20],
ChemTher [30] and Cao's work [6]. Obviously, high prediction AUCs of 0.985, a bio represents the bio-MMI feature.
b net represents the net feature.
c chem represents the chem-MACCS feature.

performance of prediction on other datasets. Although the BLM achieves best AUC(0.955) on the GPCR dataset, the average AUCs of our method (bio-MMI + chem-MACCS + net features) with feature selection is increased 0.009, 0.015, 355 and 0.064 compared with BLM [3] on the datasets of Enzyme, IC and Nuclear receptor, respectively. The advantage of our method is obvious on the Nuclear receptor dataset.

div.head: Performance on Imbalanced Dataset
div.p: We also test on imbalanced benchmark dataset throught five-fold cross valida-360 tion, as showed in Table 6. The optimized parameter sittings of balanced datasets are also employed on imbalanced datasets (including Enzymes, IC, GPCR and Nuclear). The State-of-the-Arts methods include NetLapRLS [32], WNN-GIP [26],
BLM-NII [19], KBMF2K [12], NRLMF [18], CMF [35] and NormMulInf [22] * Results excerpted from [6].

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T In this part, we test the ability of our method on identifying new DTIs. We use four biological databases (ChEMBL(C) [11], KEGG(K) [16], DrugBank(D) [17] and Matador(M) [13]) to confirm whether new detected DTIs are presence.
The new DTIs predicted by our method can be ranked by interaction probabilities, as shown in Table 8. Our method detects potential DTIs, which are present

div.head: Running Time
div.p: The time complexity of NRLMF is O(iter • r • m • n), where iter, m, n and r denoted the number of iterations, targets, drugs and dimensionality of mapping space (targets and drugs are mapped into a space of r dimensionality) [18]. The
div.formula: (N 3 s + (N 2 s + N s • d) • m • n).
div.p: Therefore, efficiency of our model is close to NRLMF (better than KBMF2K and CMF) [18].

To further evaluate the performance of our method, we test the running time on four datasets. Related source codes are collected from other researchers' works 425 [3,12,18] (including BLM-NII, NetLapRLS, WNN-GIP, NRLMF, CMF and KBMF2K). These codes are written by python or MATLAB script. We test our method and these methods on same platform by 10 times. The experiements are carried out on a computer with Intel Core i3 4160 (3.6 GHz 2-core four threads CPU), 16 GB memory and Windows OS. Detailed results of running time are 430 shown in Table 9. The running time of our method is closed to NRLMF, and shorter than CMF and KBMF2K. WNN-GIP, NetLapRLS and BLM-NII achieve the better performance of running time, but obtain the worse performance of accuracy.

figure.head: 30 dataset
figure.figDesc: can be described by three types of information in the form of three matrices: (1) the drug-drug similarity matrix; (2) the target-target similarity matrix and (3) the DTIs matrix. The drug similarities are based on the chemical structure. The target similarities are calculated based on target sequences. They used known interaction to detect new interaction with drug-drug and 35 target-target similarity matrix in DTIs network. This kind of method contains Bipartite Graph Learning (BGL) model by Yamanishi et al. [34], Kernelized

used three global descriptors (Composition, Transition and Distribution) to reflect biological properties of target sequence and encoded drug molecules with MACCS substructure fingerprint representing. Composition, Transition and Distribution (CTD) contain much information of one protein sequence. These features were fed into Random Forest (RF) model 60 for training and prediction. Zaynab et al. [20] used the bi-gram features and molecular substructure fingerprint to represent target and drug, respectively. But most of feature vector-based methods did not consider the network feature. In essence, network feature contains the association between drug-target pairs. Inspired by above methods, we propose a computational approach to identify 65 DTIs by combining three types of information: (1) properties of chemistry (chem), the substructure fingerprint; (2) properties of biology (bio), containing physicochemical properties; (3) properties of network topology (net), containing drug-target relationship of training network. In this article, we utilize MACCS fingerprint to represent drug molecule, and use MMI on sequence to represent 70 target protein [10]. The MACCS fingerprint can describe the substructures of drug molecules, and the MMI can further extract the physical and chemical

Moreover, we employ Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Feature Selection (FS) to develop prediction system for benchmark dataset. The FS can avoid the height dimension of feature and enhanced generalization by reducing the overfitting. Comparing with other machine learning algorithm, the optimization goal of SVM is to minimize the risk of structured, rather than the least risk ofA C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P Texperience. By the maximum-margin hyperplanes, SVM reduces the dependency on data size and data distribution. In practice, we find that the proposed approach achieves high prediction accuracy by combining MACCS, MMI, network feature, FS and SVM. Our method are evaluated on four datasets. The results show that the proposed approach achieves better Area Under the Precision-90 Recall curves (AUPRs) on Enzyme, Ion Channel and Guanosine-binding Protein Coupled Receptor (GPCR) datasets. In addition, we also test the performance of potential DTIs of our model on above four benchmarks. The advantages of our approach are due to feature extraction methods and feature selection methods.

Thus, we can get a [(n p -1) + (n d -1)]-dimensional f net to represent the DTI network.

To test the robustness of our approach, we repeat random selection of training set and test set, model-building and model-evaluating. This process is 5-fold cross validation. The Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic (AUC)A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P Tand Average area under the precision-recall curve (AUPR) are both used as the evaluation metrics.

Performance on Balanced DatasetWe use ten balanced DTIs datasets to analysis the prediction performance of bio, chem and net features. In the experiment, the FS technique could improve the performance of prediction and reduce overfitting. The proposed method is also compared with other good methods on the balanced datasets. 2553.4.1. Analysis of bio, chem and net FeaturesTo analyze bio-MMI, chem-MACCS and net features, we test on ten balanced datasets for each class. Cao et al.[6] used gold standard dataset and ten negative datasets randomly generated from non-interacting pairs. We use the grid search approach to get the optimized SVM parameter, and perform 5-fold 260 cross-validation on ten balanced datasets for each class. The average AUCs of our method (bio-MMI + chem-MACCS features under feature selection) is increased 0.01, 0.0061, 0.0078 and 0.0689 compared with no feature selection on the datasets of Enzymes, IC, GPCR and Nuclear receptor, respectively. SVM-RFE+CBR could improve the accuracy of prediction by 265 eliminating the noise of features. The AUCs of bio-MMI + chem-MACCS + net features under feature selection is higher than no net feature method (bio-MMI + chem-MACCS features under feature selection) on Enzymes (0.9854 over 0.9356), Ion Channel (0.9878 over 0.9355), GPCR (0.9524 over 0.8996) and Nuclear receptor (0.9452 over 0.8850), respectively. The model by bio-MMI 270 + chem-MACCS + net features indeed improves the prediction performance by adding network information. Results of prediction for these features are shown in Table3. We combine the feature of bio-MMI and chem-MACCS, named Combine1 in these tables. The bio-MMI + chem-MACCS + net feature, bio-CTD + chem-MACCS feature and bio-CTD + chem-MACCS + net feature,

figure.head: c 6 Figure 7 ,
figure.figDesc: FM represents the feature mapping of DNNE. Some dimensions of the MACCS are all 0 value. In this case, SVM can't obtain the best predictive performance. Hence we remove these dimensions of the chem-MACCS feature (by removing those dimensions of zero variance). What's more, different datasets have various network sizes, and dimensions of net feature 310 are also different. On four datasets, feature importance scores are presented in Figure Figure 8 and Figure 9, respectively. These scores are estimated by SVM-RFE+CBR. The higher score means more important. The blue, green and red bars represent the bio-MMI, net and chem-MACCS feature, respectively. 315 Obviously, the bio-MMI and net features play major roles on Enzyme, IC and Nuclear receptor datasets. On the GPCR, three types of features play almost the same effect. Through these scores, we sort them from high to low. To obtain the optimized number of top rank features, we test different numbers of dimensions (from 10 dimensions to original dimensions). As shown in Figure 10, we get 320 top 485, 245, 345 or 70 dimensions with ACC on balanced benchmark dataset for Enzymes, IC, GPCR and Nuclear classes, respectively. We utilize the grid A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T search approach to get the optimized SVM parameter for Enzymes (C = 16 and γ = 0.0313), Ion Channel (C = 8 and γ = 0.0313), GPCR (C = 256 and γ = 0.002) and Nuclear (C = 2 and γ = 0.125) with RBF kernel. And the 325 parameter of CBR is 0.9 (correlation coefficient threshold for highly correlation features).

330 chem-MACCS feature. So, the dimensions of chem-MACCS feature are different on the four datasets. What's more, different datasets have different network sizes, the dimensions of net feature are different. The DOF represents the dimension of original fusion feature (bio-MMI + chem-MACCS + net). The DSF represents the dimension of selected fusion feature (bio-MMI + chem-MACCS + net have 335 been selected by SVM-RFE+CBR). The DO represents the dimension of original sub-feature. And the DS represents the dimension of selected sub-feature.

time complexity of KBMF2K and CMF are O(iter • (r• m 3 + r • n 3 + r 3 )) and O(iter • (r 2 • (m + n) 2 + r 3 • (m + n)))[18]. Let l be the number of training points,A C C E P T E D MA N U S C R I P T

S C R I P T N s be the number of support vectors (SVs), and d be the dimension of the input data. The time complexity of training our SVM model is O(N 3 s + N 2 s • l + N s • d • l) [4], and l ≈ m • n. In most cases, N s are not at the upper bound, and N s /l 1.420So, the time complexity of our model is O

Conclusion and Discussion435Most of the previous methods are based on similarity matrix. But, the similarity matrices of drug and target could not extract more key property from drug-target interaction. To resolve above issue, a few methods were proposed on information of protein sequences and drug topological substructure. To improve the performance of prediction, we further use the molecular substructure 440 fingerprints, MMI of protein sequences and network topology to represent the drug, target and relationship between them. The results of our experiment have demonstrated the ability of the proposed approach. Our method achieves AUPRs of 0.899, 0.929, 0.821 and 0.655 on Enzyme, IC, GPCR and Nuclear Receptor datasets, respectively. 445 The major challenges of DTIs prediction include: (1) fully describing the critical information of DTIs (extracting the feature of DTIs); (2) the problem of imbalanced data. For the first problem, we utilize molecular substructure fingerprint of drug, a novel MMI feature of target and topology of network to describe DTIs information. And the MMI feature performed well. The 450 second problem of imbalanced data is common in computational biology. The performance of AUPR can also be further improved on imbalanced data of DTIs.In generally, SVM is used to handle the imbalanced classification problem by class weight. However, the performance of weighted SVM is poor on extremely imbalanced data (the ratio between majority and minority examples is usually 455 larger) and in many complex tasks. To reduce model complexity and improve computational efficiency, we only consider the model of weighted SVM (without sampling or filtering) in this study. Other better machine learning approaches, such as Neural Networks with Random Weights[1,29] and Sparse Representation model, can be used to build classifier rather than SVM. In Alhamdoosh and 460 Wang's work[1], DNNE algorithm built ensemble model with bootstrap sampling and weighting sub-classifiers. DNNE algorithm is an effective strategy to deal with the imbalanced problem. The Stochastic Configuration Networks Ensemble (SCNE)[29] is a newly developed ensemble, which always outperforms the DNNE.A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P TIn the future, we will build the classification model by strategy of SCNE or 465 even utilize the SCNE on the imbalanced data of DTIs. The ensemble classifier (with bootstrap sampling and weighting sub-classifiers) could further improve the performance of DTIs prediction. A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T [5] Cortes C. and Vapnik V. Support-vector networks. Machine Learning,

div.p: This work is supported by a grant from the National Science Foundation of 470 China (NSFC 61402326), Peiyang Scholar Program of Tianjin University (no. 2016XRG-0009), and the Tianjin Research Program of Application Foundation and Advanced Technology (16JCQNJC00200).

div.head: Availability of data and material
div.p: All DTIs datasets, feature sets, the relevant algorithm and top 500 new DTIs

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: the second best performance on Enzyme (AUC: 0.983, AUPR: 0.899) and GPCR (AUC: 0.961, AUPR: 0.821) datasets. These results indicate that the proposed method outperforms existing outstanding approaches on Ion Channel dataset, and is comparable on Enzyme and GPCR datasets. However, our method and other existing tools didn't perform well on Nuclear receptor. The main reason is 375 that the size of Nuclear receptor data set is too small and imbalance data set exacerbates this problem. What's more, the performance of our method (no net) are worse than the method including net features. Comparing with proposed method, the AUPRs of our method (no net) drop 0.226, 0.22, 0.295 and 0.198 on four datasets, respectively. Net features could help model improve the prediction 380 performance of DTIs. The average AUC and AUPR of our method are shown in Figure 11 and Figure 12.

div.head: Evaluation on Pair-Input Computational Prediction
div.p: Many computational prediction methods operated on object pairs, have been used in many areas of biology and chemistry [24,10]. Park and Marcotte 385 [21] gave the paired nature of input for pair-input methods, and evaluate their predictive performance on different classes of test pairs. Based on evaluation method [21,25] C4, drugs and targets of test set are both absence from training set. We utilize 5-fold cross validation on datasets, as shown in Table 7.

Although the performance of prediction is down in class C2, C3 and C4 on four datasets by a large margin, the performance (AUCs) of prediction is still 395 good but not significantly. In C2, C3 and C4, values of AUC fall gently by 0.048, 0.106 and 0.170 on average. Because of imbalanced datasets, values of AUPR fall sharply by 0.174, 0.431 and 0.617 on average. Tests of C2, C3 and C4 are only used to evaluate the performance of pair-input computational prediction.
